nodes.text: Individual teachers have a meaningful and measurable impact on elementary students' standardized test achievement

Method: Collected panel data (1989-2000/01) from two contiguous New Jersey elementary school districts linking students and teachers, including nationally standardized reading and math test scores on the NCE scale and student demographics and teacher identifiers

Method: Estimated linear models with teacher fixed effects while controlling for student fixed effects, classroom controls, school-year effects, and a cubic function of teacher experience (identification relies on teachers observed in multiple classrooms and students observed in multiple years)

Assumption: Identification assumes grade effects can be omitted because test scores are standardized by grade and that marginal effects of experience are zero after a cutoff (implemented at ten years) to separate year and experience effects

Result / Evidence: Large and statistically significant differences across teachers; a one standard deviation increase in estimated teacher quality raises reading test scores by about 0.20 SD and math by about 0.24 SD on the national distribution

Result: Teaching experience has statistically significant positive effects on reading (Vocabulary and Reading Comprehension) with roughly 4 NCE point gains after ten years (~0.2 SD); math subjects show little or inconsistent gains from experience

Result / Evidence: Observable classroom-specific variables (class size, classmates' average past achievement, split-level indicators) are generally insignificant predictors of student test scores in these data

Evidence: Teacher fixed effects are jointly highly significant (F-tests p < 0.001) across all four subject-area tests; 25th to 75th percentile teacher differences ~5.5 NCE (reading) and ~6.5 NCE (math)

Claim / Evidence: Estimates of experience effects that omit teacher fixed effects are biased (often downward) because teacher fixed quality and experience are correlated; comparing specifications with and without teacher fixed effects demonstrates this bias

Claim / Evidence: Teacher quality is positively correlated across subjects (pairwise correlations of estimated teacher fixed effects range roughly from 0.16 between vocabulary and others up to 0.67 among math/reading components), indicating teachers who are strong in one subject tend to be stronger in others

Limitation: Analysis is based on two similar, contiguous New Jersey districts with above-median state socioeconomic status; external generalizability to other districts or national populations is limited

Conclusion / Policy claim: Policies aimed at improving student achievement should emphasize identifying and raising teacher performance (for example performance-based indicators) rather than relying solely on traditional observable credentials like degrees or years of experience beyond early-career gains
